narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Q1 -- Readings could be updated to reflect some emerging issues (e.g.; capacity markets and other revenue streams for renewable energy and impact investing). Still, I enjoyed many of the original conceptual readings (e.g.; Rose and excerpts from the book about finance)Q2 -- Long essay assignments were a useful forcing mechanism for me to reflect and write... still didn't like them.

I thought the midterm and final were useful assignments, but somewhat redundant. Perhaps set up severalconsulting projects so that students can write papers for actual clients. I thought the small group discussions were really valuable, but there were too many questions to reasonably get through in one hour.

The PowerPoints were pretty abysmal with lots of ellipses and disorganized text. The structure and overall execution of the course material was at times hard to follow. The course needed to start off with the assumption that students had zero legal or private investment background and build from there. I felt that it was at times all over the place and that just looking over the syllabus one can see the complete chaos and overlapping themes that underscore the lack of a simple and structured approach. And although the course must be taught by a lawyer with knowledge in private investment and environmental law, it is more important-given the subject matter-that the material be organized, accessible, and structured. I found this to be the greatest weakness of the course.It was also offensive to have the TAs tick off a check mark every time the students spoke during small group to indicate participation. We are, after all, adults and I found this distracting and offensive.

Re # 4: My frustration with this course was mainly that it oscillated between being too simplistic and then suddenly too complex. More specifically, the material covered in lectures often seemed pretty obvious but as soon as we started discussing specific examples the language would get very technical and become hard to follow.
Great to learn from an actual, practicing professional in the field (rather than academic).

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Content -- focus on the role of private property in society, with specific legal tools that apply to the intersection of private property and the environment.
The small group discussions and the midterm. Mark was also really responsive to questions and had some really interesting investing experience to bring to the table.
The subject area was of great interest to me and very relevant to my career. It was helpful to have students speak up and engage in the material.
I think this course and the material covered is incredibly important for individuals interested in environmental business and law.
The discussion section was extremely helpful in reinforcing/clarifying concepts from lecture and getting different viewpoints from students with a broad range of backgrounds.

The best part of this course was that the professor gave us a great deal of flexibility in choosing what to write about in our term papers. I appreciated that we were encouraged to apply the course concepts to our specific areas of interest.

Professor was very professional and knowledgeable. Discussion sessions were excellent, a great feature of the course. Alex (TA) did a great job running ours. Great complement to classroom lectures and readings - the opportunity to discuss informally.

This course covers a wide range of concepts that are extremely helpful in advancing environmental aims through collaboration with the private sector. This applied and practical focus was great and was my favorite aspect of the course. Additionally, the readings were very helpful and often provided examples of real world applications of concepts. Also, I really appreciated that the midterm and final papers allowed each student to apply the course concepts to his/ her area of interest.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Could be strengthened by covering a broader range of environmental issues (tended to veer towards clean tech)

The lectures were a bit dry at times, and I think there were too many readings, and too many questions to cover in the small group discussions. I also think the midterm and final were too similar and felt redundant. As I suggested above, perhaps setting up a consulting opportunity with outside clients would be great.

Professor is really dry. The slides are full of text. It's really easy to zone out. The subject matter is interesting, but deAngelis was just really kind of monotone, and didn't come off as a super trustworthy source on all of the topics. A lot of people do email during class. Also, the reading list REALLY needs work. There are 20+ readings per week, and a lot of them are from the 90's. They aren't referenced in class, so there is no real reason to read them. The list really needs to be updated and shortened.
The structure of the assignments and syllabus, PowerPoints, and the overall organization of the course needs a bit of a makeover.
The lectures were often broad, and it was difficult to gain a deeper understanding of concepts.

The lectures need to be improved. Admittedly it was the professor's first time teaching this course which was actually designed by Brad Gentry but I felt that Mark was not as familiar with the material as I would have expected. The examples from his relevant professional experience were helpful but as I said before, they were ultimately hard to follow because of the technical language, jargon, and acronyms used to discuss them.I realized about halfway through the semester that my chief complaint about this class stemmed from the fact that it should have a prerequisite. I was hoping to gain and understanding of how to recruit and direct private capital toward solutions to environmental problems but I was previously unfamiliar with investments and how financial deals are structured. As a result, I often felt dumped into the deep end on assignments because I was unprepared to undertake the analysis asked of us. While I understood the concepts we were taught, I was unfamiliar with the financial tools were supposed to apply them to. This did not feel like an introductory course that was accessible to someone without a financial background.
I was satisfied with the course.

The instructor's explanations of concepts were not always as clear as they could be, and sometimes assumed a prior knowledge of business concepts and terminology that students without this background, like myself, do not necessarily have. This made it hard for me to follow the lectures at certain points. Also, class lectures tended to skip over parts of the slides that discussed sectors other than clean energy, such as forestry or climate change policy under the UNFCCC, etc, while instead heavily emphasizing the clean energy sector. I would have liked to have discussed more diverse sectors in class.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Scheduling sections every-other week would represent a better use of time.
As I said before, I thought there were too many readings and too many discussion questions for the small group discussions.

The discussion sections were just OK. Ours was fun but not super helpful to my learning. I really wanted to learn more about the financial concepts, which is my weak area, but no one in my discussion group could explain these concepts very well, including the TA.
Yes, the discussion sections and pre-written questions were extremely helpful.
I enjoyed the discussion section. While some sessions were sometimes a bit tangential and not as linked to the readings as they could have been, our discussions were interesting and informative.
Very effective.

The discussion section related directly to the concepts discussed in class each week. I found the discussion section helpful to develop a deeper understanding of concepts presented in class and to have the opportunity to discuss real world applications in sectors beyond the energy sector.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It was a great complement to other courses and provided a great overview of legal tools and frameworks for broad environmental investing.
I'm a joint degree with SOM looking at clean tech finance, so this was pretty relevant.
I had never taken a class on business or investment. Because of this, I found this course very helpful to get a broad exposure to key concepts in these fields that apply to my sector of interest.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted more of a structured understanding of ways to channel private capital into broad environmental investing using legal tools and frameworks.
I have a background in natural resources management, and wanted to gain a better understanding of the legal concepts and funding mechanisms that underly conservation measures.

I took this course to better understand private investment and how to attract it into the environmental arena. Unfortunately while I learned about overriding legal regimes, I did not get the introduction into investments that I hoped to gain in this course. I now understand some relevant private investment terminology but did not gain insights into how to structure a deal from start to finish. It seemed to be assumed that we already knew this. Since this knowledge was fairly necessary for completing assignments effectively and creatively, there needs to be a prerequisite for this course or the course needs to be altered to make it more accessible.
I wanted to gain exposure to the private sectors perspective and opportunities to engage the private sector in my area of interest in the environmental field.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Felt like a review of concepts from my undergraduate career, but it was a nice benchmark to reflect on the additional depth I've gained now at the end of my academic career.
Yes, but itwould have been great to have a bit more focus on ecosystem conservation and restoration issues; the course was very renewable energy focused.
No.

I was able to explore new concepts through the midterm and final exam as it relates to my area of focus. That experience was definitely valuable. However, I ended the semester feeling that I didnât have a strong grasp on how these legal tools fit together in reality. This may have been in part due to the fact that lectures focused heavily on energy issues.
Sadly no. Please see above.
Yes - very helpful to learn the legal frameworks. Mark offered the bridge between private finance, law, and environment.
Yes, I found that I became much more well versed in ways to engage the private sector.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: The readings are useful and good -- devote time to them!
Pick a topic you're really interested in and use the midterm and final as a way to really research and explore the topic.

If there is a specific issue that you are interested in researching(as it relates to private investment) then this is a valuable course. However, I would recommend prior knowledge of a specific environmental issue and a foundational course in finance before taking this class.
Make sure you have sufficient background and familiarity with finance before taking this class.
It is worth taking if you want to get a broad overview of how to engage the private sector in your area of the environmental field.
